description.text: Extruder Carriage with Integrated Cooling, Lights and Reduced Part Count

This started out with a ducted carriage inspired by Chylld's (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15044). Before I knew it this had taken on a life of it's own. The current iteration of this design has:
1) Eliminated 4 components from the original Rapman carriage assembly. This has lowered the extruder assembly ~5/8" and raised the extruder nozzle the same. This brings everything in closer to the center of rotation (axis rods) as the machine whips about doing it's duty. There is also the use of Plaster of Paris to arrest heat conduction to the plastic carriage from the extruder. Accommodations for this can be best seen in the top view.
2) Widened the carriage in both directions. ~7/8" from the front view and ~1 1/2" from the side view). This gives the carriage a wider stance and therefor greater stability.
3) Conversion to plain bearings instead of recirculating ball. While gathering dimensions for the design I discovered glaring errors. The parallel of the axis rods was off. Using precision gage blocks I found the X Axis to be .038" out of parallel. Using a vernier caliper (I don't have gage block that big) the Y Axis was out by .068"!! When I corrected the problem I was amazed as how sloppy the carriage had become. I cannot imagine anyone with this machine not having a similar situation. This theory is somewhat validated by comments posted on blogs. Some saying they have grooves worn in the rods while others comment on the development of back grit. Obvious signs of wear from over-loaded bearings. The source of the over-loading being misalignment. The design of the machine really has no datum origin and as such is it impossible to create a square and parallel condition, no matter how good the corner supports are.
4) Lights; I toyed with using acrylic light guides for light, but that was too expensive and complicated. Now the design will have a series of LED's illuminating the nozzle, not shown to give a view of the nozzle.
5) Integrated cooling ductwork with fan. The ducting has pillars inside to support the square shape. I have printed a test and it went well for this design. Based on conversations with fellow 3D printer enthusiasts it sounds like a trimmer pot for the fan is in order. This will allow a more precise control of the airflow. A PWM fan output would be nice, but would require advanced knowledge of the cooling. Of course that would be gained just like the other settings. Not shown is a top plate that will screw to the carriage as a target for the limit switches. I originally was going to us outriggers to stiffen the carriage and still use the recirculating bearings, but ultimately plain bearings won and the outrigger idea was abandoned. So please comment and question liberally...Thanks!

title: Housing for Pi Zero with MakerSpot stackable USB-hub
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a housing to protect your precious Pi Zero paired with MakerSpots stackable USB-hub.
I have tested it and customized it for Raspberry Pi Zero V1.2 and MakerSpots gen-2 stackable USB-hub.

The housing consists of two parts, the bottom part wich holds the hub and the top-part wich holds the Pi.

The bottom is tight but the hub fits, and is secured by 4 pcs M2.5 screws with a maximum lenght of 6mm.
The top-part is also secured with 4 pcs M2.5 screws with a maximum lenght of 6mm and has one hole for the GPIO header and one for a 12mm x 12mm heatsink.

Both pieces are then fit together and secured by 4 pcs M3 screws (i used 12mm long ones).

The plastic spacers, screws and nuts delivered from MakerSpot is not needed with this.

EDIT: 2017-10-15, Added a new TOP-part without holes for heat sink and GPIO header (requested by maferreira).

This is a remix of jrebeiro's ID card holder, sized for one regular card and one thicker RFID card.

In my case the cards already had a hole through the top so having one on the holder was redundant. I pulled it into Tinkercad and made short work it. While I was doing that I angled the channels so the cards can slide in easier. Then brought it into Meshmixer to round off the corners and smooth the sharp edges.

I cut off the metal clip from my lanyard, and reattached the ends with some super glue. I flipped it over so the card slides in on the back to give the front side a finished look, all the way around.

Pictured here left to right is:

  • First iteration - customizer wasnt working for me so i brought it into Tinkercad and sized it manually. Angled inner channels.
  • Second iteration - that was pretty good but it had too many sharp edges for comfort. brought it into Meshmixer and smoothed it off
  • Third iteration - chopped off the top and smoothed it out again

comments.text: Works great! I needed a holder that shows both sides of the card.  Had to mod it to add a ring on top as my ID card doesn't have holes (and punching them out is not an option), but that too seconds to do.  Thanks for such a great design.

14th Oct 2016 - Been flying with 3 of my own packs and I'm very happy with the performance. Battery should be secured into the case. I'lll look at the model with holes in it and see when I can think of. I will also upload a model without any cut-outs so people can do there own cutouts like @kraftor80 did.

29th Sep 2016 - Used smaller holes at the terminal end to prevent balance plug falling out of the hole and causing a jam.Rounder sides tested in a print. Very happy with results.

26th Sep 2016 - Rounder sides.

Just a little update. Model 07 has rounder sides. Seems to fit in a little better.

9th Sep 2016 - New versions !

I have updated this model. The original one had the locking pin a little out. This one locks even better.

Made the battery easier to grip and shortened the locking pin si it's not too hard to remove but still keeps the battery in firm.

Designed to use 2 dean's plugs and a Multistar 4S 8000mAh battery. It can take other's if they fit.

With my print settings the Holes version was 26 grams and the Solid side version was 42 grams.

*Print in ABS or another medium that is good at hot temperatures. Don't use PLA.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OcbOo-fLCcU

Tarantula

Assembly: For a permanent battery assembly.

Remove unneeded pins from dean's.
Test fit Dean's into 3D model.
Insert battery leads through holes for deans in 3D print.
Solder deans to the lead's.
Double check your polarity...
Glue dean's into 3D model. Make sure it's flush.
Slide battery into 3D print. Glue of doublesided tape if needed.

Tuck 4S balance lead into the 3D housing to keep it out of the way.

This is nothing but a test piece for evaluating how a printer prints holes. The rectangular part is 15x15x5 mm, the small hole has a diameter of 3 mm, the large hole has a diameter of 6 mm.

The FreeCAD source file is included although honestly, it's about as simple a project as possible. Basically the 3D equivalent of Hello World, but if you want to see how FreeCAD works at the most basic level, it might be worth looking at.

This is the clip holding the visor in place.
Drop the helmet and you might have use for it……

I used PLA so i needed to use my needle files for minor adjustment.
The original is very flexible, the ordinary PLA is not...

title: Eachine E010 Stick Handle Extension - Tiny Whoop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The stock transmitter that comes with the Eachine E010 is awful, very hard to control the sticks. Here is my handle extension, which hugely improve control and comfort.

There are two different height of the extension: 15mm and 20mm, choose one of them. I would say 15mm is for thumbers, 20mm is for pinchers. I personally prefer 20mm as control is more precise.

Usage

  1. Print 2 of them for each stick
  2. Use a zip tie to hold them together

Here is my tutorial how to turn the Eachine E010 into a Tiny Whoop:
https://oscarliang.com/eachine-e010-tiny-whoop-inductrix/

For more awesome E010 Modifications, check out this post:
https://oscarliang.com/eachine-e010-mods-1/

title: Toyota 4Runner left arm for rear cup holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The rear cup holder in our 2000 3rd gen Toyota 4Runner had seen better days. The left arm had snapped off and was lost forever. This isn't an exact copy of the original, but it's close enough that it works in all the ways that matter.

To make sure I don't break this one also, I'll be sure to bring the arms together before jamming the cup holder into the center console.

comments.text: That's EXACTLY the one my kid just broke. SWEETTTTT!
comments.author: AllTerrain

comments.text: Good times. Sadly, I no longer have a 4Runner. It had a terminal case of frame rail rot. A 3 foot long by 1-3inch high hole/gap along Both frame rail box sections that extended from the front upper section of the rear axle bump all the way forward. Was missing half of the skid plate on the fuel tank too.  Rust belt... Such a great truck. The engine and drive-train worked great, but the rust ate her alive. Still miss it.
comments.author: AllTerrain

comments.text: They almost look like left and right are the same arm. Can you confirm this?
comments.author: KeeganH

comments.text: The right and left arms are nearly mirror images of each other, but not quite. The end of the right arm goes up while the left arm goes down. The hinge pin details are also not identical from top to bottom.
comments.author: KeeganH

title: Solidoodle 2 Complete upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Most every upgrade i have made to the solidoodle 2, would be useful for solidoodle 3 as well.

One part is missing and that is the small L shaped plate that hits the endstop switch and yes its very important, will upload later.

Will update and add directions as requested. Marked as work in progress as there is always room for improvement but as is the parts are working very well on my printer and i have logged around 100 hours of print time since the upgrade.

I'm able to print at higher speed while retaining the surface detail. 40mms works on most prints with a max of 60mms for travel which used to top out at 30mms and 45mms for good detail.

The Z anti backlash upgrade is the most noticeable improvement on surface detail and i recommend everyone print and install this upgrade before anything else so the rest of your upgrade parts come out nicer.

You will need a few M3 aka 3mm nuts and bolts of various lengths. I couldn't tell you exactly what i used as i simply bought every bolt in every length ace hardware hard in stock. Very useful little bolts to have on hand for printed projects. Reuse the M5 nuts and bolts for the idler pulleys.

Printer:

Solidoodle2 - HicTop Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Print at what ever settings gives you the least warping, with all of my models i try to account for shrinkage.

PETG or ABS will be the best option with PETG proffered due to low warping and a higher heat deflection which matters with the hot end mount.

The bearing mounts tend to be a little lose so print with a high infill so they print a little fat and a couple layers of kaplon tape around the bearings gives a nice and secure fit. The tape also makes it easier to snap them into place.

author: chev383

title: Alien walker, it can take itself to your leader

description.text:
This alien won't ask you to take it to your leader, it can get there by itself.
I scaled up gpvillamil's standing alien by 4x and modified the leg area.  Then took tbuser's walker negative, made some changes, and combined them.

Printed on a Prusa with one extra shell, 5% infill, speed at 30mm/sec took about 90 min. You'll want to keep the infill low so the weight doesn't get to be too much for the walker mechanism. You may need support, depending on how your printer is tuned, for the top of the cavity and the slot for the turn key. The walker mechanism is available from the MakerBot store: http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-windup-walkers.html Once I get my printer tuned for ABS I want to print it in glow in the dark. Which you can also get from MakerBot. The OpenSCAD file is attached.

This is a replacement part for the acrylic T-bottom for CowTech Ciclop 3D Scanner

So the bottom piece of the T bar broke for me so I made a new one from the dxf file used to laser cut it originally.

A version of Walter's Customizable Case to fit a Raspberry Pi Zero, 8MP Camera Module, 3.7v 700mAh LiPo, and PowerBoost 500 Charger. I will need to modify the case with a Dremel tool to make a peep hole for the camera and to fit an external hard power switch.

This is a WIP, so I'm not yet sure how long it will be able to record on a full charge with only 700mAh. Updates and pictures to follow.

PRO TIP: If you are very brave you can remove the camera's IR module and make it a night vision camera (which works fine in daylight, albeit with some odd color resolution). You will also need an IR illuminator for this (I like this one for $13: https://amzn.com/B00M3MQL9W)

Estimated Project Cost: $77 +shipping from adafruit, a cool $100 if you go the night vision route. This is not including filament/material cost, nor mSD card and switch as I have tons of these things laying around.

If you have your own printer I estimate the material cost to be around $0.08USD (with average FDM PLA which usually costs me around $32.95; Aurora brand filament if you are interested in what I prefer. This is also assuming basic/normal print settings with an Ultimaker2+).

Parts:
Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 Camera Pack (zero, ribbon, and camera): https://www.adafruit.com/products/3170 $39.95

PowerBoost 500: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1944 $14.95

LiPo: https://amzn.com/B01HUEJZCW $12 (2 pack, can maybe arrange them in series for 1400mAh)

DIY Guides:
How to run Zero via lipo: https://github.com/NeonHorizon/lipopi

RPi setup of Motion software (this is old, but still works for me as of August 2016): http://www.instructables.com/id/Raspberry-Pi-as-low-cost-HD-surveillance-camera/

Updated Motion Setup: https://scottontechnology.com/raspberry-pi-webcam-server-using-motion/

Remove Camera Module IR filter (at your own peril!): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HtjkNyEt4xU

3d printer design based completely on Nophead's Mendel90 concept. Note that this design is totally untested as of right now. If you want to make one, head over to the irc #reprap in freenode, and look for Stevetronics. I'm working on documentation, but I need to finish mine first. As you can probably see, this has been stagnant for quite some time - I'm working on it still, but I strongly recommend that you don't make this. Nophead's is better engineered all around, and a better bet if you want community support.

remixed_from.author: 0110-M-P
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3 (B/B+), Pi 2 B, and Pi 1 B+ case with VESA mounts and more

remixed_from.author: j4c3
remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini 75mm VESA Mount (for Pi case)

description.text:
This is tagged as a remix because the hole positions are repurposed from 0110-M-P's RasPI case mounting holes for 75MM VESA mounting and is based on the MP Select Mini Mount designed by j4c3 and was created in Tinkercad.

The Project box comes with two holes pre-fabbed for mounting the quad-relay board on Amazon (Just search four relay board raspberry pi and you'll find it). Other than that, the walls and lid are left blank to provide the most flexibility when it comes to cable routing.

The box features eight captive bolt slots (#6 nuts and bolts are used in the attached pictures) and is designed to have some strength to it to hold the bolt in place while the screw is tightened. That being said, don't go all hulk on it and try and apply 50ftlb of torque on the screws. Little bit tighter than hand tight will give you good solid connection.

This is my first project from conception to print and I'm pleased to say that I've been met with some level of success. Just ignore the fact that it looks like Cthulhu is holding the nuts in place.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Defaults

Infill:

20% i think

Notes:

You can use whatever settings you want although I do recommend supports for the captive bolt locations. Admittedly, I found this out the hard way when it printed, but there's enough of a gap there for me to get the nut in place and have it hold securely.

title: Colt Pistol With Silencer split ready to print

description.text:
My boys had watched a classic spy movie and were intrigued by the pistol with a silencer.
So I made a couple for them to play with. They look really good and the lads are enjoying playing good guy bad guy in the yard. You can size them up or down to what ever you like. I just positioned them on a 200 x 200 print bed comfortably and carried over the % size settings when printing the other half. I cut down a couple of old bolts and glued the thread into the silencer for easy removal. Roughly about a two our print each side and ABS ascertoned/glued together, sand and paint done ; )

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's my first attempt of using Fibonacci sequence to create a flower.

The petals form a golden spiral and several spirals form a flower. In the customizer, a larger spirals makes the petals density higher, and a larger petals_per_spiral generates a bigger flower.

After generating or downloading a STL here, scale up it to the size that your printer can print the smallest petal.

The printed thing here, for example, were enlarged to a scale of 1:3.5.
Want to know how I design it? Take a look at Golden spiral.

description.text:
The Spiral Light Baffle is a 1-1/2" od tube with baffling to permit a 1" id through. Pipe threads permit attachment to other baffles, or lens holder caps or lens holder plugs. Lens holders with pipe threads attach to baffles and can mount filter/lenses either with fine-threaded retainer rings, or metal set-screws, or simply press-fit. Pipe threads permit multiple assembly, so light-tight tubes can be constructed with integrated filters for low-ambient-light precision optics.

Using OpenSCAD, all dimensions are scalable. Tubes can be labelled/embossed with text strings to distinguish differences. Logo engraved on back.

OpenSCAD files are fully customizable--mount type, lens diameter, tube length, thread patterns-- though if adjusting threads, it took some iterations to find parameters that printed well on a Ultimaker2 with PLA plastic.

Plans to make more pipe-thread connectors--4-way cross, lens-holder with pipe-threads on both sides, mirror mounts with x/y fine adjust... The goal is to make a light-tight optics-bench experiment.

title: Divided Parametric Box and Lid (Metal Stamps, etc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a OpenSCAD file that can be used with the customizer app to generate your own item boxes with dividers. This was originally designed to hold metal stamps, with particular emphasis on having dividers, so that when one stamp is taken out, the others do not fall out of order. If you have alphabet stamps and a box with no dividers, it is not long before they are all mixed up and you have to hunt for the right letter. This is still a work in progress. Pictures of printed boxes will be uploaded soon.

UPDATE 1 - 9/2/16:

  • Updated the SCAD file to be more generic and not specific to stamps
  • Added a lid tolerance parameter. This is useful if the lid is too tight to fit the box due to material or printer accuracy differences.
  • Fixed the ability for choosing to generated a lid or not, and to generate a box or not. Useful if you already printed a box but need a lid or visa versa.

description.text:

description.text:
A light duty support to keep the chain & bar off the workbench. Will allow chain rotation.

Body:
Designed to be printed at 100% speed. Uses 5 x 50mm bolt & nut. GoPro handle will also work. Two 5mm nuts can be used to pull bolt into place by using a second nut on handle. See image.

I added a piece of inner tube (or equal) to the side pad & rounded the bolt end. Body may be secured to a block of wood. Allowing bar support to twist may break it.

Bolt Handle:
Was designed to be printed with the following criteria. Larger base portion @100% speed with tapered part & small end @ 50% speed using 0.3mm layers. Pull bolt into handle with a over-sized nut & a 5mm nut.

Different print speeds will result in slightly different internal diameters. Slower knob base print speed will make the hex hole larger, faster print speed on the tapered portion will make the hole smaller and deform the end. A timer will help with the speed issue.

Outer Guide:
May be used if chain sharpening.

Clean holes with a 5mm drill bit after cooling if necessary. A little crazy glue will secure rubber pad.

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the 7" Waveshare 1024x600 HDMI capacitive touch LCD screen v2.1 designed for use with a 3D printer with OctoPrint with the TouchUI plugin.

The mount assembly is kind of garbage but the enclosure stands on its own, the mount is only there to provide a magnetic anchor so the LCD doesn't vibrate off the table.

The idea is that the LCD is attached to a Pi via the HDMI and USB cables and is able to be picked up, worked with, and returned to the table in front of the printer. The bezels on the side are intentionally large to allow a good grip without interfering with the touchscreen.

Automatic backlight control can be added via a one-wire mod.

Printer:

C-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

Use gap fill to fill the walls to make them solid

Use #4-20 3/8" plastite screws to hold it all together from the back side, #4 3/8" wood screws might also work. The back holes are clearance holes so they should be drilled with a 1/8" or 3mm or 3.5mm drill bit. M3-0.5 machine screws can also be used if all the holes are drilled through, but obviously the screw heads or nuts (your choice!) will show in the front. Both the HDMI and USB cables need right-angle adapters so they come out the back instead of the side.

The slot in the back of the case is for a ferrous metal bit to be glued in for the magnet to have an attachment point.

The magnet recess in the mount is designed for a 1/4" / 6mm x1/16" / 1.6mm disc magnet, but like I said, this mount is garbage so I am interested in hearing of others can come up with something better.

comments.text: hi friend, good job. why did you choose the position of the screen vertically and not horizontally? I use it horizontally but I do not like the scrool of the screen that gets caught up with the touch. rotating the screen vertically there will be to change the touch?
comments.author: nettunoroberto

comments.text: Because all the tabs in the OctoPrint TouchUI scale better vertically than horizontally. If I had done it landscape, then I'd have to scroll on the temperature page to get past the graph to change the temperature. I'd have to scroll past the print status bit on the first tab to select a file to print. There's just more controls on every tab in portrait than there are on landscape.
comments.author: nettunoroberto

comments.text: you're right, in fact vertically it makes more sense.

print_settings.Notes:: Only the BaseTop needs supports printed.  I tried flipping the basetop over which surprisingly didn't clean up as well as it usually does.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Hello,
This is a remix of just the base to be used with version 1 of the Stranger Things sign. The first time I did the remix of the sign I needed help to properly back light the sign. This base allows for the lights to be built in and illuminate it on it's own.

I stretched the base to the length of the sign, hollowed it out, and cut off the bottom.
For the top of the base where the sign goes, I drilled out 5 holes for LEDS to go through.

This is definitely a work in progress since there's not enough room to hide a 9V in the base. I was hoping the sign would illuminate better but it's a good first attempt.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

30

Notes:

Only the BaseTop needs supports printed. I tried flipping the basetop over which surprisingly didn't clean up as well as it usually does.

Base setup

I glued the basering to the base just so there's something to keep the basetop aligned with the bottom and prevents it from moving around.

Keep trying to flip this image but it always comes out upside-down.

Oh and LOL I am being serious and not making a bad Stranger Things pun :-p The base picture really does keep displaying upside-down on here.
I used Meshmixer to hollow out the object then cut off the bottom. I also made a slice and resized for the basering to allow it to sit right inside the basetop and prevent it from moving around.

comments.text: Very nice idea... and a terrific look and feel!!
comments.author: thekhanagain

comments.text:
Thanks,
Yeah this is the first time I tried remixing a model this extensively and I'm glad the basic setup worked well. Just didn't take into account the battery size and I think the Red LEDS are a lot dimmer then the white LEDS I bought from the same place.
comments.author: thekhanagain

print_settings.Notes:: 4 bottom and top layers

title: Low Profile Tension box for enable Gauntlet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the Team UnLimbited Gauntlet V4. My goal was to integrate the gripper box into the gauntlet itself so it can be very low profile on the wrist of the user.

This release contains all the required files to create thermo-formed gauntlets for e-nable devices and is currently compatible with both Raptor Reloaded and Phoenix hands. Printed in PLA the gauntlet is heated when printed to form a natural, strong gauntlet. I did not include the forming jig.

I designed the bolts around M2, M3 and M4 bolts. These are pretty readily available with various head types and lengths. The fabrication guide will eventually have a table to match the scale of prints and the required size bolts. The bolts are meant to spin freely in the plastic. So those holes need to be drilled out after printing for most sizes. The end nut should be a locknut. It is the captured nut in the whippletree that moves.

The cover is thermoformed seperatly and slides into the holding slots. For best results heat the cover and quickly form it over your already formed gauntlet by sliding the cover into the slots. Before the cover is set, remove it from the slots and bend it slightly more and let it harden. This way the cover is slightly tight and holds better to the slots.

This is still a work in progress, and is provided here for beta testing only.

Printer:

IMade3d

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35% honeycomb

Notes:

4 bottom and top layers
The bolt holes will need to be drilled out, depending on printing scale.

comments.text: Well done Jacquin! This is an interesting alternative to the whippletree for adaptive gripping and I like it! I look forward to hearing from your beta testers.
comments.author: MacGyvrBot

author: JacquinBuchanan

description.text: This is a part that I designed to be glued to a wall in pairs. It will then hold a pole between the two.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

10+

Story

I needed a solution to suspend my full spools of filament in my airtight storage container. I designed this as the solution to the problem. It can be easily glued to the wall of a container, ane will support a circular rod where you can suspend your unspent filaments.

Edit: Watch it in action! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MO4cYjVboyQ I'm building a plotter based on two DVD laser carriages. Parts I will print, and eventually some photos of the progress will be shared here. If you're building a similar project, you can use these parts as a base, but you may have to modify them to your needs. For the pen carriage, I'm using two steel rods taken from another laser unit. I've printed the carriage in PLA, and then drilled the holes to the diameter of the rods (3mm). The PLA works excellent on the steel rods without any lubricant.

description.text:
Improvement to Cfeniak elegant and clever Rain Water Diverter. (thing:351234)
Now you can build it in any 3D printer.
Splitting it in two sections makes it easy to remove leaves and debris that might get trapped inside.
Designed a sleeve that fits both parts together, glue it to the bottom section only so you can remove the top as needed. When putting back together make sure to insert the "nose" first.
You can put a few drops of crazy glue to permanently attach the pipe to the diverter´s body.
Pie should be built horizontal and at 100% infill.

author: MichaelAtOz

description.text:
These models are examples of student work on a project on special relativity in a multivariable calculus class.

The first, lightcone.stl is a schematic model of a light cone (represented with two spatial dimensions, plus time), illustrating where in space time one can get to under the restriction that one cannot travel faster than light.

The second gives a possible resolution to the Ehrenfest Paradox: what happens if you try to spin a solid disk at relativistic speeds? The paradox lies in the fact that the outside of the disk will undergo greater Lorentz contraction than the center. The students decided that a possible resolution would result if the disk curled upward, thus reducing the circumference at the edge. Their calculations and an interactive widget are here, and the reldisk.stl model illustrates a disk, and how it might curl if spun fast enough.

Conversation heart candies are delicious, fun, and often funny. However, have you ever wished you could have something more updated (and personal) to give your sweetie than something that says "fax me"?  Enjoy these simple conversation hearts that are easily customizable and reusable.

I made these using Schmarty's Inkscape to OpenSCAD plugin https://github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-openscad-poly. I have included the source .svg I used incase you want to create your own conversation heart! I printed these on a thing-o-matic (can't wait for my replicator to arrive) using 0 shells and 15% infill. If you create your own from the .svg I recommend using the IMPACT font, and be sure to convert your text to a path (and then combine the letters so your phrase is only one path in OpenSCAD).

I needed this to replace i3zBRACKET.STL and i3zCLAMP.STL in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:576932

Update:
I eventually went with this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752086

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1264391

A box for containing a cheap chinese LM2596 DC DC buck converter.

Intended usage:
1: Drill a hole and mount a DC-jack on one side of the box.
2: Drill holes and mount positive and negative banana plug connectors on the top face of the box.
3: Drill a tiny hole just above the trimpot on the LM2596, so you can access it with a small screwdriver.
4: Solder wires from DC-jack to input on the LM2596, and from the output on the LM2596 to the two banana plug sockets.

The result is a cheap adjustable DC lab power supply (assuming you have a DC PSU between 12-24V to actually power the LM2596 with).

This is a simple charm that can be worn on a thin chain to express your love of extreme weather.
Let's hope for some thundersnow this Valentine's Day!

I made these using Schmarty's Inkscape to OpenSCAD plugin github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-openscad-poly. I have included the source .svg I used incase you want to express your love for less extreme weather conditions.
I printed this on a thing-o-matic with 0 shells and 15% infill.  
The rings are designed for a chain that is 1mm thick.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro 8mm-bolt holder for spool holder

description.text:
There are many spool holders for the Flashforge Creator Pro. Some use a bolt or rod. I'm not reprinting the existing parts for holding the spool on the rod, only the part to hold an 8mm bolt (I use 120mm in length).
This was created in sketchup and carefully checked for any hidden artifacts inside or for flipped surfaces, and then converted to stl.
The stl file will print fine with Flashprint.
The stl file will result in bogus code and sometimes crashes with Simplify3D. If anyone has an idea how to change the stl file so Simplify3D can understand it I would very much like to know.
If you place two of these on the "printbed" and slice with Simplify3D it produces two different bogus versions. So really, do not use Simplify3D to print this (at this time).

Edit: I added a fixed stl thanks to Doug Kightley from the Simplify3D forums. It appears my nice model in Sketchup was not translated to a good stl file by the sketchup to stl converter I have as a plugin in Sketchup. Maybe it's too old...

description.text:
The stepper motors driving our printers move in "steps" of varying size. The majority of the steps are in between full steps. Full steps are the strongest magnetic positions. When the Z axis is positioned in between a full step it migrates to the full step that attracts it most, turning the lead screw and changing the layer height. Thus each Z layer height not set to a full step value while printing becomes smaller or larger than intended. Over multiple layers this will affect Z height accuracy. I used the RepRap calculator to find several favorable layer heights that will eliminate this problem. This is a PDF with the next higher and lower full step value of common layer heights for printers using common 5/16 ACME rod (which has .2728 pitch). the HIC Prusa uses these rods. If your printer uses these rods add a tag to this post. if your printer uses different rods create your own schedule and post it as well. Or ask me to include it.
For other size and pitch Z axis rods Here is a link to the calculator.
http://prusaprinters.org/calculator/

title: Settlers of Catan Magnetic Pieces Modular Box

description.text:
I was searching for a way to wrap my amazing catan game I found here on thingiverse in a similar great box. So I came up with what you can see in the pictures. This upload is just about the sorting box for the land and water tiles but I will also upload the other parts.

Sorry for the german naming of the stl files, but i was to lazy to rename them.
here is the important part:
There are piece-holders with 12, 21,26 and 36 mm spacing in between. All piece holders are interlockable.
You will need
12 mm for Water and dessert
21 mm for wood, sheep, grain, gold as well as for the brick tiles without housings on top of the hill
26 mm for the larger bricks and the water pieces with the island
36 mm for the iron mountains.
then you will find two special pieces for the largest road and largest knight trophy, that also leave enough space for dices and number plates as well as a front and back cover "Abdeckplatte".
All tiles have to have the magnetic base . Otherwise there is to much gap between the tiles and the holder, so they will shake to much.

In the pictures you can see a version for 6 players with the water extension. (27 water, 4 dessert, 7 resource tiles of each type, 4 gold and the two trophies). For this setup, you will need 3x12mm, 7x 21mm, 1x26mm, 2x36mm and each of the special trophy parts. I placed them in 5 rows, meaining you will need 10 end covers.

Make sure you have enough plastics laying around, as this is not a material saving design, but therefor quite stable and reliable.

This is a governor, similar to what was once used on steam engines.  It is meant to be attached to the drive train of a rotary device.  As it spins, the arms are pulled upwards by centrifugal forces, causing the plunger in the center to move down.  Normally this would be used to apply a brake to the device, slowing it down.  Esentially, it's a primitive form of speed regulation.
I built this without any application in mind, so it lacks attachment points and so on.
Print one of each piece and assemble them with 40mm-long m4 bolts and nuts.

comments.text: this is very helpful I've been designing a gramophone to print and this is a lot simpler than what i came up with
comments.author: onerian

comments.text: These little guys are why you can't really fall and die in an elevator anymore, they are attached to breaks and mounted on a threaded rod and bearing. The faster it falls, the faster it spins, and that makes the arms lift and presses the breaks into a breaking belt or rod, to slow it down. Some have latches in all 4 corners, these days, controlled by accelerometers and hydraulic actuators, but i'm referring to something like a 1950's elevator.

comments.text: If I were king for a day I would make it mandatory that all spinning things require one of these old style governors.  Nice remake of a device which always makes me smile  :) .

title: Anet A8 alternative 40mm Extruder Fan Mount

description.text:
This bracket allows you to remove the 40mm fan and heatsink from the extruder and mount the fan above the stepper motor.
It also provides strain relief to the cables going to the extruder.

It has been tested with extruder temperatures up to 245'C and the extruder top block remains cool to the touch.

Moving the heatsink and fan away from the end of the extruder allows better access when loading filaments and also reduces fan noise.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

Doesn't Matter

Mounting

Remove fan and heatsink.
Screw the extruders top block to the stepper using 2 x 20mm M3 screws.
Remove the top two M4 screws on the top right X axis linear block.

.Attach the bracket to the J-Frame using the two M4 screws that go back into the Linear Block.

Mount the fan and guard to the the bracket with two M3 screws and nuts so that the fan blows downwards

Use two small cable ties to fix the extruders cable harness to the bracket to provide strain relief.

comments.text: Do you think this mod have problems printing ABS? You need a higher temp on the hotbed(100-110°)
comments.author: tittaz

comments.text:
It should not be a problem.
The A8 is known for having a dodgy heating bed.
If you are going to use ABS then install an additional Mosfet unit to switch the bed heater on and off, its not safe to keep the bed at 100'C using power form the main controller board, the connectors are not rated for this and there have been many reports of them catching fire.
Also, its worth insulating under the heat bed so you dont loose any heat downwards. (This will allow the bed to heat up faster)

comments.author: gavincol78

comments.text:
This mod cools the top of the extruders throat just as well as the stock fan does, if not better.
The stock fan position just cools the front of the stepper in order to cool the throat whereas this mod cools the entire stepper, ie more cooling area.
In the months that I have used it, I have never had any clogging issues even when running PETG at 250'C.
On the contrary, it has made changing filament a lot easier and no more breaks when trying to get filament in or out.
Also I have had no bad feedback from people that are currently using it.
The only bad feedback has been from people that have not tried it and just assumed that it does not work.
All I ask is to keep an open mind, give it a try and then post your results.
comments.author: gavincol78

comments.text: I guess mounted this way it blows down on the heat bed and beside using more energy for it that would also cool the first layer of the print which many also would say is a bad thing. As much as I like the idea to have easier access to the nozzle I worry that it would limit what you can print.
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text: Nevertheless it seems to work pretty good. I measured temperatures and all looks good so far. I really like the direct access to the extruder! I will try some prints with higher temperatures soon. As most air going down on the backside of the motor I was thinking to enclose the era on the right side. I tried that with some bluetape and the airflow is much more horizontal than.
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text:
I tried many configurations of mounting the fan.
This way proved best, it blows into the J-Frame and not onto the bed, the warm air is vented horizontally out of each end of the frame and not downwards.
So no worry about it cooling the bed or the print.
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text: Well yes that actually makes sense. I forgot to take the J-Frame into account. I may even try it. Should be easy to test how hot every thing gets when careful testing some prints.
comments.author: SentinelRX5

comments.text: Well I currently try it and it blows a lot of air onto the bed. Not sure how you measure airflows :)
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text:
It shouldnt blow air onto the bed, the stepper and J Frame is in the way, its should however blow air out horizontally but not downwards onto the bed.
If you place your hand to either side of the stepper you will notice air coming out horizontally (Left and right)
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text: The fan is there to prevent the extruder motor from over heating due to heat transfer from the heater block. This apparently works as well and makes it easier to access the extruder feeder area.
comments.author: opticor

comments.text: I think you may have the concept of that side fan wrong as I have read that it is to keep the filament guide area cool to prevent melted filament from clogging up the extruder and yes it may help towards exhausting motor heat but keeping the feed area cool is more important. Look at the E3D extruders, there is no motor on those extruders yet they need a fan to prevent filament from clogging before going to the hotend
comments.author: opticor

comments.text:
When they designed this extruder assembly they put a heatsink on the steppers mounting block to help cool the extruder throat, the design is a generic one as they did not know how it would be implemented.
As the A8 uses a large aluminium J frame this sinks the heat away better then the heatsink.
The whole point of the fan on the extruder is to keep the throat cool at the top and prevent the filament from melting as it enters the throat.
comments.author: gavincol78

comments.text:
My initial disagreement stands.
I tried this and I got 'heat creep' I then since changed to an E3D v6 and used the same stepper motor in a bowden setup and not once had an issue with the motor getting warm as I didn't keep the fan on the stepper motor. The fan and heatsink design is there to prevent 'heat creep' from the extruder and from me trying it and got heat creep it proves my point.
comments.author: SentinelRX5

comments.text: printed this and wish this design work for me, but unfortunately it didn't, learned a new term 'heat creep' from gavincol78, did a lot of research and can confirm removing the heatsink and fan away from the original position will produce a heat creep problem causing filament to stop extruding. This problem happen to PLA and ABS too, I can still print pla if I put the heat sink back and still keep the fan blowing above the stepper, but for ABS, I have to revert back to original setup to able to print successfully. Thanks for the work anyway SentinelRX5.
comments.author: gavincol78

comments.text: Quick Update:
comments.author: SentinelRX5

comments.text: That solution won't cool the lower part where the hotend is connected right? Will that be a problem? If not, i don't see any need for a fan at all. The other motors on the A8 aren't cooled either...
comments.author: opiswahn

comments.text:
You will still need the front circular blower fan to cool the item you are printing.
This mod just gets the square fan and heatsink out of the way so you can access the extruder gear area better.
Noise from this fan is reduced quite a bit and when you need to load filament, you can see where the hole is in the throat.
I mainly print with PLA and the top block that the throat screws into remains nice and cool.
comments.author: opiswahn

comments.text: Just wondering... is that fan isn't realy needed, why is it there in the first place?
comments.author: SentinelRX5

comments.text:
Without active cooling the top block of the extruder would get too hot, With PLA it would probably be ok, but anything hotter and the throat will not function correctly.
You can try it without cooling, just unplug the fan from the board, but you risk clogging the hotend throat and would have to replace it.
comments.author: opiswahn
